segments.text: It's going.
All right.
I guess we'll start over again, because I don't think that one was working.
And Mrs. Adams, you were telling me about going as a bride to Mexico.
Well, my husband was superintendent of a mine up in the mountains.
And it was a mine that was halfway between Saltillo and Monterey.
about two miles off the railroad.
And we only lived there a short time because the revolution came along and we had to leave.
And then finally, we were in and out of Mexico for two or three years then.
And that's how we came to live in San Antonio because this is our stopping place in between times.
And we finally did go back to the mine
And then Mr. Adams had a, let's see, he was transferred then over to Ahuela, which is near Torre칩n.
He was with the Pe침oles Mining Company.
And it was from that mine up above Saltillo where
The bandits came in and took him out and held him for five days, held him for a $25,000 ransom.
That isn't much compared with what they get these days, but it was a great deal then.
I was in Los Angeles at the time, and this was the...
I just collected the...
Those clippings had been laid away for, I guess, 50 years.
And when we sold our home and moved into the apartment, these came to life.
And so then I put them in a book and saved them.
But they held him for five days out in the hill country.
Finally, they paid the ransom and came back.
It was a very pleasant experience for him.
Nothing happened.
They were very good to him.
All they wanted was money for the revolution.
What particular group of people?
Well, they claimed to be Peroncistas at the time.
That was when Carranza was in power.
And when they came to rescue him, he said he was sleeping on a...
on a blanket with a soldier on either side of them sleeping on their guns.
And when the men came up the trail at 10 o'clock at night, one of them said, Kim Beebe, who comes?
And one of them said, Carranza.
And the other said, Villa.
So they were evidently divided, you see.
The men who were holding him claimed to be
The men who were holding him came to be viestas and they arranged then for the ransom to be paid out of the, from the mining company office in Saltillo.
He came out all right.
He was only gone five days, but I was in Los Angeles and it was just,
two months before my son was born.
So I didn't meet any of these newspaper men.
My father was an old newspaper man and he met them out on the porch of our home there in Los Angeles.
My parents lived in Los Angeles.
Of course, he was trying to fend off the reporters, and I wouldn't see them.
So all of these things that were in these press notices were very disturbing to me because they were garbled, you know.
And every time a newspaper would come out, I'd just go into hysterics.
Well, when did you first hear that he'd been kidnapped?
Well, I had...
He was a very...

almost providential thing because I took my daughter who was then four and went on the streetcar which was at 5th and 6th and Coronado and went down to the corner of 7th and Broadway on the streetcar.
I was just getting out of home because I had had the flu the week before and I wanted to get out.
And I heard these people calling the extras on the other two corners across.
But I got off on this corner and walked directly across the street to get my bus back home.
And they were calling all about the American kidnapped in Mexico.
And it didn't down on me that it was my husband because they'd had so much trouble down around Fresnillo and the mines down there.
And I just thought it was, just because it was Mexico, it was disturbing.
And I got home and my father was out on the back porch just nervously looking at these newspapers.
And I said, well, Dad, you might as well bring the papers in.
I know about it already.
Then I looked at the headlines and I said, well I didn't know it was my husband.
And then of course I called the telegraph office, Western Union, and they said that they had had a consular message for me and they'd been trying to locate me.
This was on a Monday.
They'd been trying to locate me since
Saturday.
This didn't happen on Friday night.
And because I was visiting my parents, who were named Adams, you see, they had, they had, they were named Kemp, and they were canvassing all the Adams in the directory.
And so, of course, as soon as I identified myself, I got the
message from the consulate in Saltia and from the mining company.
It was the American Metals Company in New York.
And I got my messages from them.
They assured me that that was in here the
They assured me that he was.
This is the message.
Your husband, held for ransom by Mexican rebels, have just received word he is being well treated.
This office and the company doing everything possible to procure his release.
And this was February 16, 1920.
So this was actually rather late in the revolutionary period.
Well, it was an interesting experience.
He came out all right.
There's never a time when it's very convenient to have a thing like that happen.
Not exactly.
No, I shouldn't think so.
Well, when you were first down there, you were talking about going down to Mexico and your trousseau going by Ox Park.
Now, when was that?
Well, that was in 1918, I guess.
My son was born in 1920, and this must have been 1916, because my daughter was two years old at the time.
So it was very primitive at that time, of course, because we didn't even have the
the highway between Monterey and Saltillo at that time.
We could go from Monterey, we could go from the mine to Saltillo.
We had a little Ford car.
We could drive that to Saltillo.
But to go to Monterey, we had to go on the train.
And it only came lots of times.
It was two days late coming through.
So it was very primitive.
Did you live at a mining camp or in a village?
We lived in a mining camp, and there was no one there, but I went directly from Los Angeles, and I didn't know any Spanish at all.
There were no other ladies in camp, and there was a sort of hotel for the bachelors.
of workers and a Chinese cook, and they were down the hillside from our house, and we had this house up on the hillside, and a very nice, I think I have a picture of that.
This was, this doesn't,
do much for your recording.
Oh, that's all right.
It'll be fine in the transcript.
Mary, you can look at it in just a moment.
Why don't you go stand over here?
Well, here is the Pancho Villa.
Oh, this is Pancho Villa?
Yes.
He came in.
He visited my husband several times at the, uh, this villa.
Uh-huh.
But he was at the smelter.
You see, the mining camp
This was down in Ahuela, near Torreon.
This is the one near Torreon.
But not where I live.
Now, are you in this picture?
No.
This was taken down at the, not at the mine, but down at the smelt area.
See, the mining company had the, this mine in Ahuela, where you are, is very interesting.
It's a beautiful mountain country.
What did your husband used to say about you?
Did he talk about you much?
Well, he was very, he came to call on my husband.
He was in the hospital with an accident of mine.
He was very, very agreeable when he came to call.
Of course, you felt you had to handle him with gloves because he was supposed to be very temperamental, you know.
So I guess everybody handled him very carefully, but he was very considerate.
He came to call on Mr. Adams in the hospital and asked about his health, if they were taking care of him.
But the houses at this mine are so interesting.
The mining group.
Were most of the miners North Americans?
Well, this mining company that Mr. Adams was with was the Pinole's Mining Company, which was a Mexico division of the American Metal Company.
And it, in turn, was a subdivision of the German Berlin Gasol shop.
Of course that was, you see this is ancient history.
That was 50, more than 50 years ago.
I can't believe sometimes it's that far back.
This is the place where they had a strike and all the miners came out, see them on top of the building?
Yeah, was there any trouble with strikes in the mine?
Oh yes, we had numerous strikes.
And in the morning, when Mr. Adams would get up and go down into the patio, our house was on the hillside, you'd look down into the patio.
When I'd see these Serapis and Sombreros milling around the patio, then I'd know that there was a strike on, that they weren't going to work, you see.
They had numerous, and they had old battles back and forth during the time.
You see, Mexicans lived in these little, they called them cuevas.
They would go to dig them back into the hillside where it was warm, you see, and have their sleeping quarters back in these cuevas, as they called them.
Then they put a sort of a patio effect out in front, and when it was warm weather, they would live out in this patio.
And when it was cold, they'd go back in the hillside.
Very friendly.
And these were the people that worked in the mines?
Yes, yes, those were the workers.
These were the ox kind.
I wanted to show you that hillside, which shows all their houses, which I thought was very interesting.
That's some of the workings in the mine.
The battles, did you actually see any of the battles?
No.
See, most of the revolution was over by the time I went down there.
We were married in, I don't know, I'll be able to tell you the date, but I always forget it.
I think it was 1913.
And my husband had gone down to Mexico.
He graduated from Stanford.
He worked for a little while for the Miami Copper Company in Arizona, and then he went to Mexico.
And he came out, I remember, in 1910, when they had a revolution down there.
They were always having a revolution, you know.
It was a very mountainous country.
This was the mining camp where he
Is this the one in Torrey Yard?

Well, no, this is there in Harris, where he had a mine, an accident in the mine, had a hole of rock hit him when he was, had knocked him down, had a fractured vertebra, and they carried him down this, on a,
A very rude litter with a blanket, you know, with two sticks on either side.
Mine was very high up.
Yes.
Well, he had a very checkered career.
This was a bull fight.
Now you say he had to leave or was it... Oh, there shows all the pot marks when they were taking and retaking this town of Torreon.
Uh-huh.
And the houses were just full of cannonballs and bullets and everything else.
But did you all, until the bandits came, did you feel terribly threatened by any of the things that were going on, or did he, or did they pretty much leave him alone?
You always had a, when you're young, you know, those things don't affect you very much.

I guess we really felt a little uneasy all the time, because when I first went down there and Betty was a baby, I kept a little satchel packed with her baby food and her bottle and her diapers and all, so that if we had to get out on short notice, we could leave.
And one night, this, we were,
We had been told that the bandits were roving around the station, which was two miles down from the camp.
And so we went to bed rather uneasy.
And then there was a, we kept a watchman outside the house all night long.

They had a system of alarms all over the camp, so that if there was a bandit alarm, he would ring on an old rail in the backyard, you know, soundless alarm, and the watchmen at the different levels over the mine would answer it, so that the whole camp would be alarmed.
And in the middle of the night, he came to our window and he said, here they come, I'm in.
And Mr. Adams asked, how many?
And he said there were five bandits and they were on the trail back to our house.
So Mr. Adams said, well, sound the alarm.
So we heard him go back and sound this alarm.
And we got into our clothes as quickly as we could, and I wrapped the baby in a blanket and got all ready to go down to the mine.
And Mr. Adams took me down to the entrance of the mine.
There was a little railroad that went into the entrance of the mine.
And he left me there with the assistant superintendent, and he went back up the trail to wait for the bandits.
And the three burros came down the trail.
So it was much less threatening than it had appeared.
We went through all the thrills, as it were.
So we had a number of... What about the common people, the miners and people like that?
Did they talk very much about what was going on, or were they very much afraid?
Well, no, they were not.
They were a very ignorant class, and all they wanted was a livelihood.
They wanted the mine to continue and get their money.
And of course, if they didn't
That was their only means of support because there wasn't much agricultural pursuits around there.
They had small ranches, but they were owned, you see, the ranches were owned by the money-class people, and these workmen could only get day's wages wherever they worked, you know.
They didn't have much, much prospect of
substantial living.
And of course they, most of them, mining was all they knew.
This was a lead and zinc and some silver mine.
And they had, they brought it out on little, of course they had stoats in the mine where they knocked the ore down into these little carts.
and they ran it out to the entrance of the mine in the carts, and then they loaded it onto a tramway, which was a system of trestles and buckets that ran down the mountainside, you see, and they
The filled buckets, the weight of the filled buckets taking the ore down was sufficient to bring the empties back up, you see, on this tramway, they called it.
That was interesting.
I think that tramway is still there.
You go on the railroad to, between Monterey and Saltillo, it's about halfway between Monterey and Saltillo.
But the...
The Mexican government has taken over all those mines now.
They're government controlled.
And I don't think that mine was good enough.
It was rich enough that they probably aren't mining it at all now.
But during the war days, you see this was during the war days that we were down there.
And we had to get all our supplies through the American consulate in Monterey.
I remember when we wanted, Betty had the lupine cough and we wanted, I wanted special food for her because she didn't seem to be able to take the food that we were giving her.
I remember I was paying a dollar, a dollar and a half for a little can of the
more than sweetened milk, you know.
Condensed milk?
Condensed milk, yes.
But not the, it's the sweetened kind, you know.
That seemed to be all sweetened.
At one stage, we had a goat, and we gave her goat's milk, and they

The Mexican people that you met down there were very friendly, and I remember this woman who lived over at the ranch that sent our vegetables in from the Jewish, and she had sent us milk, but we didn't have to boil it.
Of course, it didn't do very well, but she said that the child should have goat's milk and have it warm right from the goat,
And so the Mexican mozo, he'd come in and I'd have him scrub his hands in the kitchen, wash them very clean, and give him a little cup with a linen cloth to strain it through.
And he would go up on the hillside and he'd milk the goat and strain it right into her cup and she'd drink it.
Well, that was the thing that this Mexican woman told me.
How did it work?
It worked.
It worked very well.
Because we'd been having to send the secretary, a boy from his office by train down to Saltillo to bring the milk back, you see.
So this didn't work very well.
But we had a number of very primitive experiences down there.
It seems so long ago, I haven't talked about it for so long, it's hard to remember.
Do you remember approximately what the miners made each day for their labor?
I just don't know what the prices were.
Of course, they were paid in Mexican currency.
Right.
I think the ratio was two to one at that time.
Of course, that has changed a good many times, you know.
Then at one time, when Mr. Adams was kidnapped by these bandits up above Saltea,
He wasn't paying them.
He was paying them in script, which they'd have to take down into the city to get cashed, because he didn't dare keep money at the mine.
And that was the reason, really, they took him out when they kidnapped him, was because they asked for money, and he said he didn't have any money.
And because he was paying in script,
And so they said, well, we'll have to take you with us until we get our money back.
And that's how they did it.
Was this a regular point?
Did the bandits do this regularly?
Was it something to be expected?
I mean, were the bandits kidnapping people for money during this period?
Well, this happened.

There had been a good many kidnappings about that time, and I think one of these clippings in here tells about how Villa had said that he was going to capture 12 Americans, and until he got his money back, Villa claimed

that he had sent his representative up with money to buy supplies, and the man had absconded with the money, and he said that until he got his money back, he was going to kidnap Americans and hold them until he was reimbursed.
Now, this was actually after Pershing had left Mexico, wasn't it?
Yes.
Yes.
So V was still actively...
But you say these men did not claim to be V. Eustace.
Well, the men that...
The men that took him out claimed to be V. Eustace.
They were all...
I think there were about 12 men, and they all seemed to have...
colonel status.
Twelve colonels?
My goodness.
They were all colonels.
And one of them even was a mason.
This was very queer.
Was your husband a mason too?
No.
Well, no.
His father had been a mason.
Mr. Adams went to Mexico as a young high engineer right out of college and never had
taken up, he really never had settled himself any place to be affiliated.
His father had been a nation.
The men that held him, were they
Did he describe them as being fairly well educated?
They were all fairly well educated.
They were not the class of men that he'd been working with in the mine at all.
And he said that as they gave him a horse to ride,
He said as they rode, they could see the Federal troops in the distance, but they never caught up with them.
He said they didn't try.
The Federal troops were supposed to be out trying to locate them, you see.
And he said they could see them as they were driving, riding along, and they would camp at the different, well I guess common, just commandeered
Any ramps they came to, they would just require them to feed them and feed their horses.
But they rode over the hills for five days.
Did he ever hear from any of these men later?
Did he ever find out what happened to them?
No.

The man who came to rescue him was, had been at one time, his name was Gutierrez, and he had been one of those interim presidents, well, president probably for a day or a very short period at one time in Mexico.
And when he came, he came out to
to rescue the saddles.
And he simply gave his word to the bandits that he would bring them their army.
So he acted as a go-between.
And they released your husband before they had the money?
Yes.
But this man Gutierrez, of course, we've always thought that he was in on them.
because he merely gave them his word that the money would be paid to them.
And I think he went into the office in Saltillo and collected the money and took it out to them.
Very simple.
But it was just one of those things.
This is the mountains there.
When we moved and I discovered these, I knew these clippings were there in a box of papers and all the shadows had.
But my son, who was born just after this kidnapping, had never seen them until we moved about four years ago.
So it was very interesting to him and his family.
Two of his children were up here with him the night
We were looking for the release papers on the property we were selling and had to have an abstract that had not been filed and should have been.
So we found all these clippings.
Did your husband ever go back to Mexico after?
Yes, we went back to Mexico, and we lived in Monterey after that, and he was Assistant General .
And then they had a very, well, they had a general shakeup in the administration, and a good many of the old employees left.
And we came up here and went into the packing house business with friends, and spent 30 years in that.
About what year was it that you came here?
Well, we came up in 21, about a year after this event.
We came up in 21, so we've been living in San Antonio since 1921.
That book needs repair.
It's home to pieces.
Yes, it has.
That was his track suit there in Stanford.
My friends always said his middle name was Billy Stanford Adams.
Well, did your husband ever comment about, since he saw so much of the Revolution, did he have any opinions about it?
Did he ever talk much about whether he thought it was worthwhile or just a waste of time?
The Mexican governments, you know, have been so... One regime will go along easily, you know, and then the next one comes along and it's completely over.
It's just a series of that sort of thing.
And of course, during the time that he was down there, it was all so...
revolutionary, you know.
Not nearly as stable as it is now.
Of course, they say it isn't too good, but it's a lot more stable than it was then.
At least they have a set government now that seems to work.
Did you get to know any of the Mexican women?
Well, you see, when I was down there, we were out in the, out at this little mining camp, and my only connection was with the ranch people that came in, and with the miners' families.
You know, the master mechanic down there was a very nice Mexican, and very capable.

I went down to Frank Brothers to buy some shoes not long ago, and the clerk that was waiting down there came with Medellin, and I said, did you happen to come from the Medellin family in the garrison?
He said, yes, that was my father.
Wasn't that queer?
How did he happen to come?
Well, I think the whole family came up here, and they were living out on the...
I knew of them, and I knew when they came.
I mean, I...
Mr. Adams had known of their being here, and that the whole family came up here.
He was a good mechanic.
Of course, I don't know of what sort of, you say he would have in, in, in locating here, but he evidently managed to.
And then when my daughter came, was married, she,
married a young lawyer here in San Antonio, and never had any idea of going to Mexico.
Of course, she had learned Spanish before she learned English from the nurse down that we had for her.
She was four or five when we left Mexico.
And her husband had grown up in Brownsville,
And he spoke excellent Spanish.
He was a graduate of Suwannee and of the University of Texas.
And he was one of the young lawyers that was chosen to go into the auxiliary service for the embassy in Mexico City.
So he served as an auxiliary officer at the embassy in Mexico City.
And they lived down there for three years.
And then he went on to Washington.
He went to Houston first with the law firm there, and then he went on to Washington as the Assistant Secretary for Latin America.
What is his name?
Collin.
Henry Collin.
They had a very interesting experience.
three years at the embassy in Mexico City.
In fact, Henry spoke such good Spanish, that was when Mr. Messerschmitt was the ambassador in Mexico.
Henry spoke such good Spanish that he did all of the public appearances in the hospital that he sort of pinched him and told him when he had his Spanish.
Oh, excuse me.
It was a very interesting life for them.
I'm curious, did you ever hear from Gutierrez again?
Did your husband ever hear from any of these people that had kidnapped him later on?
Or hear what happened to him?
No, I don't think he ever did.
I never thought about that.
I think perhaps they just melted into the, they took their money and ran.
Because that was all, that was all they wanted.
There was nothing, it wasn't anything personal.
They had no...
a particular claim against him, they just wanted their money, and he said in this write-up in his book, he said they apologized any number of times for taking him out if they did.
They were very, very polite and very solicitous for his comfort.
Of course, they said they had to have their money.
They knew they would get it.
They knew that the mining company would pay it because they paid it for other men.
They had taken other men out.
I think the superintendent of the smelter had been taken out to the health events and the mining company had paid it.
So it wasn't an uncommon experience.
Was anyone ever killed?
by this particular group of men?
No, I don't think so.
They were not violent men.
They just needed money for the revolution, like I said.
Five days on horseback.
Was your husband accustomed to riding horseback?
No.
He had a free saddle sword at the end of that five-day.
Well, he never complained.
He said it was a nice horse, and they promised to give him a horse, but they never did.
They just traveled around, and really it was an area not far from this mine, because they doubled back to the mine finally to get, I don't know, six or seven supplies, or I'm sorry to say that.
It almost seems this would be gasoline because it wasn't.
We had that little Ford car at that time that we used to go back and forth two miles from the mine down to the station.
Of course, at this other mine where he was taken, where he was kidnapped, it was even off the narrow-gauge railway.
You had to go by muleback for a couple of miles to get up there.
It was very isolated.
And I guess that was the reason they dared come in there and take him, because it was off the line of communication.
Things were...
It was interesting at the time.
I wouldn't want to do it now.
It sounds like you've had a lot of very interesting experiences.
Well, it was interesting at the time.
Of course, I didn't think about it at the time.
It was very foreign to my experience because I had grown up while I was teaching in Los Angeles at the time we met.
I had never been to Texas or Mexico.
I'd gone to New York and traveled from Los Angeles to New York and Virginia and the east, but I'd never been south.
So it was all new to me.
I knew no Spanish.
So I learned my Spanish by the hand and foot method.
When you came to San Antonio, did you make your friends among the people that had lived in Mexico?
Yes, many of our friends were people who had lived in Mexico.
We still have the nucleus of those friends.
There are lots of people in San Antonio who have lived in Mexico at one time or another.
still find a new case.
And a good many of the, of these men who left the mining business about the same time as Travis did were, some of them settled here, and some were in Denver, and he was
Why do you think so many people left that business right at that particular time?
Well, it was an aftermath of the war, a reorganization of the company.
It was largely German-dominated.
All the head men were prominent Germans.
And I think it was an aftermath of the war at that time.
Well, now, how did that work out?
During that time period, we were at war with Germany.
Were there any complications?
Well, yes.
I can't quite remember.
All the mining interests were taken over by the government because they were German interests.
Right.
And I don't know just how that was...
Of course, this company that Mr. Evans was employed by was the American Metals Company, but it was owned by the German interests, and all the head men who came down to the mine were German.
But it was taken over by the government at that time.
By the United States government?
The United States government, yes.
Were there any mining engineers from other countries besides the United States down there?
Oh yes, there were very many of them.
In fact, Mr. Adams' first mine superintendent was an Englishman, Mr. Gluck.
He was an Englishman, but he was working for this
German company.
And we had, it was, probably had quite a few Germans working for them.
It was not entirely German.
It was, several of the men I picked up were English, and a good many of them were American mining men, because I can't remember them all.
Were any of them Italians?
No.
I don't remember any Italians in the organization.
There were Germans, and there were Swiss,
What about Mexicans?
Were there any Mexicans in the supervisory positions?
Not in the head positions.
I can't remember of any of the officials being Mexicans.
Of course, there was a large, in Monterey, when we were living down there, there was a large colony of German settlers down there, quite a large group.
In fact, they had a German foreign club.
I remember so distinctly when I, when Mr. Adams had this accident over at the mine,
And we went to Monterey.
He was in the hospital there.
And we were moving at that time from one station to another.
And I needed to buy some pajamas.
And my Spanish was very, very poor.
And I went into a men's clothing firm there in Monterey.
And in my very poor Spanish, I told him I wanted sleeping garments.
I wanted two-piece sleeping garments.
This is a very small man that came away on a small stature and rather a dark complexion.
I took him for a Mexican.
And in my terrible Spanish, I explained what I wanted, and he answered me in perfect English.
And he was a Frenchman and president of the foreign club.
And I said, why did you let me struggle along with my terrible Spanish?
He said, it was such fun to hear you.
So that was the year we went.
After he got out of the hospital, we went back to Monterey and spent the year there.
And then we left.
Did you know of many Mexican families that left Mexico during this period or earlier, during the Revolutionary period?
Well, I didn't happen to know them.
Because if I say we were living in the country, you know, at this mining camp.
And the miners themselves, were they pretty well staying?
Well, they were pretty...
Well, they were so poor, you know, they couldn't go any place.
They had to stay right there.
I meant to ask, did they actually, they with their families, live up at the mine, or did they live down on their ranches?
Oh, no, these men that worked in the mine lived right there at the mine.
With their families?
Yes, with their families.
And they were, that was their home.
They had no other home to go to.
Of course, I suppose when the mine closed down, they spread out in the country and probably lived with relatives or got jobs on ranches and wherever they could or went to another mine.
Of course, there were lots of mines in Mexico.
This was one of the rather smaller mines there.
The larger mine over in Torreon was
There were several thousand there around your town, but this was just a little mining camp, which was very poor.
Did most of the men have wives and children, huh?
Yes.
Yes, there were lots of wives and children at the camp, and they seemed to be a very happy bunch.
They had their own little market, and...
have their little carnivals and all.
Were they all from that part of Mexico, or were they from different parts of Mexico?
No, I think they were pretty much from that district, right around here, about several generations back had worked on this, in the mines around.
Of course, that was their profession, mining.
And it was really very dangerous because it was primitive, you know.

They had these stoats in the mine where they'd go up what they called chicken ladders, you know, to go to the top of the stoat, you know, and dig the ore out and throw it down, you see, into these parts on this little railroad.

very primitive and very dangerous they had lots of accidents what did they do mine no it was lead and silver with a lead and zinc and some silver but uh about when had it been open my husband go down to open it oh no no it was an old mine was in i don't know how

there were two mines there in fact one was the cabrillas line and the other was over the mountain the garris mine but there were two mines there but the main mine was where we were where our camp was and we had a very nice brick house built on the hillside we had a had to have a watch from there day and night because
There was a trail right back of the house that led over the mountains, and that's where the milk pen came in.
And then there was usually, there was this road down, sort of follows the railroad track there.
And we often had, that's where the train master down at the station would come up and tell us that the bandits were milling around the railroad station.
Unless they had some particular objective, they didn't come up to the camp.
Your miners, did any of them go down and join any of the revolutionary groups, or would you have heard about that?
Well, we wouldn't have heard about it.
They may have, but...
Of course, when they went on strike, what they wanted was their money.
They wanted more money, might I say.
What did you do when they went on strike?
Did they get more money, or what?
Well, they had to negotiate with them, just like they do now.
I suppose I really didn't enter into that, so I really don't know.
Eventually they'd go back to work, and I suppose the mining company would agree to meet their terms or whatever they...
You mentioned a lot of accidents.
What did these people do when somebody had been injured in an accident?
Well, they had a doctor there.
They had a doctor.
He was very poor.
Of course, he met their needs.
And then, of course, the company had a Canadian doctor in Monterey, which they would send that.
And the staff had this accident, which was fine.
They sent the Canadian doctor down.
In fact, the other company had their own rolling stock.
They had an engine and a car, too.
They called it the side door Pullman because it was a boxcar that made over into a Pullman.
They eventually did have a Pullman car.
But when we first went down there, it was the boxcar with the
living quarters in it.
They thought that the hill was special.
Did you learn that the Mexican women had quite a bit of medical lore?
Well, yes.
It's a good hill like the Mexicans are here, you know.
They always, they have their, I've forgotten what they call them, the women who
They really do an awful lot of doctoring before they call in a medical doctor.
Old remedies, I suppose.
Did you ever use any of them?
No, I never did.
Except the goat.
Well, the goat.
Yes, I used the goat.
But it was a...

I remember several times when we were invited over to this ranch place for a meal, and how very courteous, and I know they just were convulsed by Spanish, but you could see they were amused, but they weren't just courteous at all.
And of course, there's so many words infused with Spanish.
There's so many words, you know, that...
confusing because they have the same word, they have several different words for the same object.
For instance, my little daughter, I've heard the word down there for umbrella, sombria, and she came up here and they called it a parasol and an umbrella, so she called it a sombrelasol.
The people that owned this ranch, these were the owners of the ranch?
Yes, they owned the ranch.
They weren't the same class as the miners?
No, and there's really a caste system down there.
They felt very superior to the working, and they feel very superior to the hired hands that they have to do the manual labor on.

on the ranches so there's really quite a feeling of aristocracy about it they were very early i i enjoyed the contact down there your pleasures were very simple did they uh well uh i don't remember ever entertaining them
a meal or anything.
But no, I don't think they did.
They did come over to, she would send her mosso over, you see, for a pile.
We didn't have a water supply.
And they had to send the water over in jugs, two big jugs on either side of the boiler.
And of course we boiled the water.
And then the vegetables.
